name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: MIT - Position, Velocity, Acceleration

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: You should always begin a problem by defining a coordinate system. Here, Lewin defines \( + \hat{x} \) to be up to the right.

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: Average velocity: \[ \bar{v}_{t_1, t_2} = \frac{ v_{t_2} - v_{t_1}}{t_2 - t_1} \]

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: Velocity is a vector quantity, thus a negative velocity means motion in the negative \( \hat{x} \) direction. This comes out nicely in the way that the average velocity is defined as a change in displacement over a change in time.

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: On a graph of position-time, average velocity is just the slope of the line connecting two points on the graph.

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: There is a big difference between speed and velocity! Speed is a scalar quantity, measuring how fast an object travels but says nothing about its direction -- it is the magnitude of the velocity. Thus, if an object travels out some distance and then back to its starting point, it will have a zero average velocity (since the net displacement is zero) but its speed will be non-negative.

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: The instantaneous velocity is just the derivative of position, \[ \mathbf v = \frac{d \mathbf x}{dt}  \]

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: End of introduction to velocity

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: Introduction to average acceleration

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: Average acceleration: \[ \bar{a}_{t_1,t_2} = \frac{a_{t_2} - a_{t_1}}{t_2-t_1} \]

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: Acceleration has units of meters per second squared.

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: Instantaneous acceleration is just \[ \mathbf a = \frac{d \mathbf v}{dt}  = \frac{d^2 \mathbf x}{dt^2}  \]

name: Introduction to Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
note_content: End of Lesson

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: Example: \( x(t) = 8- 6t+t^2 \)

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: \[ v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 2 t - 6 \]

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: \[ a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt} = 2 \]

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: Types of questions in kinematics: What is the velocity or acceleration at time \( t \)? What is the time when the position or velocity is a certain value?

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: Making position, velocity, and acceleration graphs.

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: General expression for position and velocity under constant acceleration.

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: \[ v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = C_2 + 2 C_3 t \]

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: \[ a(t) = \frac{dv}{dt} = 2 C_3 \]

name: Example with Position, Velocity, and Acceleration
Video Description: MIT - Example with Postion, Velocity, Acceleration (Lecture 2)
note_content: End of Lesson

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: Introduction to vectors and vector addition

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: When writing out solutions, an "x" on the paper indicates a vector going *into* the page, while a dot indicates a vector coming out of the page.

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: In general, Learnstream will use "math boldface" to denote vectors. Thus, \( \mathbf a \) is the vector \( \vec{a} \).

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: Adding vectors - The sum of two vectors \( \mathbf A \) and \( \mathbf B \) can be found by placing them head-to-tail and drawing the "resultant" as shown. This is useful for understanding the geometric significance.

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: A "negative" sign in front of a vector simply means the vector is flipped by \( 180^\circ \).

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: Subtracting vectors can be achieved by adding the negative of the vector you want to subtract.

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: The triangle inequality addresses this idea -- \[ |\mathbf A + \mathbf B| \le |\mathbf A| + |\mathbf B| \]

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: Decomposition of vectors - We can "project" a vector onto each axis to get its component in each of the orthogonal axis directions \( \hat{x}, \hat{y}, \hat{z} \). This is called "vector decomposition."

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: Any vector \( \mathbf A \) can be decomposed such that \[ \mathbf A = A_x \hat{x} + A_y \hat{y} + A_z \hat{z} \]

name: Introduction to Vectors
question: What is the magnitude of \( \uvec y \)?
explanation: \( \hat y \) is the unit vector pointing along the y-axis. Because it is a unit vector, it has unit length, or magnitude of 1. Thus, \[ |\hat y| = 1 \]

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: The magnitude of a vector \( \mathbf A \) is just \[ |A| = \sqrt{A_x^2 + A_y^2 + A_z^2} \]

name: Introduction to Vectors
question: What is the magnitude of \( \mathbf B = 3\hat x - 2\hat y + 6\hat z \)? (number only)
explanation: The magnitude of a vector is given by \( |\mathbf B| = \sqrt{B_x^2 + B_y^2 + B_z^2} \). Thus, we compute \[ |\mathbf B| = \sqrt{3^2 + (-2)^2 + 6^2} = \sqrt{49} = 7 \]

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: The magnitude of \( \mathbf A = 3 \uvec x - 5 \uvec y + 6 \uvec z \) is just \[ |\mathbf A| = \sqrt{3^2 + (-5)^2 + 6^2} = \sqrt{70} \]

name: Introduction to Vectors
note_content: End of Lesson

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: Multiplication of vectors

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: The dot product (sometimes called "scalar product") is defined as \[ \mathbf A \cdot \mathbf B = A_x B_x + A_y B_y + A_z B_z \] Intuitively, the dot product is multiplying parallel components of vectors, and the result is always a scalar.

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: The dot product can also be found by \[ \mathbf A \cdot \mathbf B = |A||B| \cos \theta \] where \( \theta \) is the angle between the two vectors when they are put tail to tail. Both above definitions are equivalent, and sometimes one is easier to compute than the other.

name: Multiplication of Vectors
question: Let \( \mathbf A = 3 \hat x - 2\hat y + 5\hat z \) and \( \mathbf B = 1 \hat x + 1\hat y - 4 \hat z \). What is \( \mathbf A \cdot \mathbf B \)? (number only)
explanation: We compute the dot product as \( \mathbf A \cdot \mathbf B = A_x B_x + A_y B_y + A_z B_z \) and so \[ \mathbf A \cdot \mathbf B = 3 \cdot 1 - 2 \cdot 1 + 5\cdot (-4) = -19 \]

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: Example

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: The dot product of perpendicular vectors is always 0

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: Cross product explanation.

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: Geometric definition of cross product - \[ \mathbf A \times \mathbf B = |A||B| \sin \theta \]

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: Right hand rule for determining the direction of a cross product. The result of \( \mathbf A \times \mathbf B \) is *always* perpendicular to both \( \mathbf A \) and \( \mathbf B \)!

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: \[ \mathbf A \times \mathbf B = - \mathbf B \times \mathbf A \]

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: Difference between left-handed and right-handed coordinate systems is very important! We always use a right-handed coordinate system, such that \[ \hat{x} \times \hat{y} = + \hat{z} \]

name: Multiplication of Vectors
question: How can we test if two vectors are perpendicular?
answer: Two vectors are perpendicular if their dot product is zero.
explanation: We can see this from the geometric definition of the dot product -- \[ \mathbf A \cdot \mathbf B = |\mathbf A| |\mathbf B| \cos \theta \] The cosine will be zero for \( \theta = 90^\circ \) or \( \theta = 270^\circ \), both of which produce perpendicular vectors.

name: Multiplication of Vectors
question: Let \( \mathbf A = 5 \uvec x + 7 \uvec y - 2 \uvec z \). What is the z-component of \( 5 \mathbf A \)?
explanation: Multiplying a vector by a scalar will "scale" the vector -- \[ 5 \mathbf A = 5 \cdot 5 \uvec x + 5 \cdot 7 \uvec y - 5 \cdot 2 \uvec z  = 25 \uvec x + 35 \uvec y - 10 \uvec z \] Thus, the z-component is -10.

name: Multiplication of Vectors
note_content: End of Lesson

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
note_content: Problem setup: An ice skater is on an ice rink, holding a \( 0.15 \text{ kg } \) ball. She throws the ball exactly straight forward, with a velocity of \( 35 \text{ m/s } \). The combined mass of the skater and the ball is \( 50 \text{ kg }\). We want to calculate her velocity after she throws the ball.

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
note_content: We define our coordinate system -- \( +\hat{x} \) is to the right.

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
question: Why is momentum conserved in this problem?
answer: Momentum is conserved because there are no *external* forces acting on the system. The ice skater does exert a force on the ball, but the "system" we are conserving momentum in includes both the skater and the ball (and thus that force is not "external" to the system). We are also only considering momentum in the \( \hat{x} \) direction, thus we can neglect the normal force and the gravitational force, which act in the \( \hat{y} \) direction. Because the skater is on ice, the frictional force (which might act in the \( \hat{x} \) direction) is negligible.

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
question: What is the initial momentum of the system? (number only!)
explanation: Because all components of the system are at rest (ie, their velocity is zero), the initial momentum is just zero: \[ p = m_{\text{skater}} v_{\text{skater}} + m_{\text{ball}} v_{\text{ball}} = 0 \]

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
note_content: It is usually best to work symbolically, and plug in numbers at the end. This reduces rounding errors, and allows you to see the abstract relationships more easily.

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
question: What is the final momentum for the system?
answer: The final momentum is still zero, because momentum is conserved! Conservation of momentum means \( p_i = p_f \).

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
note_content: \[ v_{f, \text{skater}} = - \frac{v_{f,\text{ball}} m_{\text{ball}}}{m_{\text{skater}}} \]

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
question: Why does the skater have a much slower final velocity than the ball does?
answer: By Newton's third law, we know the force exerted on the ball by the skater and the force exerted on the skater by the ball are equal and opposite. Because the skater is much more massive than the ball, by Newton's second law ( \( F = m a \) ) she must have a smaller acceleration than the ball for the equivalent force!

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
note_content: You can think about Newton's third law in terms of conservation of momentum. If two bodies interact with each other in the absence of external forces, momentum must be conserved. If Object 2 experiences a change in momentum \( \Delta p_2 \) from the force exerted by Object 1, to conserve momentum it must be that Object 1 experiences a change in momentum \( \Delta p_1 = - \Delta p_2 \). But, this change in momentum must arise from a force exerted by Object 2, and since the changes in momentum are equal and opposite, the forces that produced them must also be equal and opposite as is required by Newton's third law!

name: Conservation of momentum example - Ice skater
Video Description: Khan - Example - Ice skater throws a ball
note_content: End of Lesson

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Beginning of lesson on Newton's Laws

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Newton's first law originated with Galileo's Law of Inertia.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Newton's first law: **Bodies at rest will remain at rest, and bodies in motion will continue to move at constant velocity along a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.**

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Newton's first law does not hold in "non-inertial" reference frames, that is, reference frames that are themselves accelerating.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Your reference frame (standing on earth) is actually non-inertial, because the earth is rotating about its axis and is also orbiting the sun, both of which give rise to centripetal accelerations. These centripetal accelerations, however, are very small.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: To estimate the size of the centripetal acceleration at the equator, we calculate: \[ a_c = \omega^2 R \] we can find \( \omega \) as \[ \omega = \frac{2 \pi}{T} = \frac{2 \pi}{3600 \units{s/hr} \cdot 24\units{hr}} \approx 7.3 \times 10^{-5} \units{rad/s} \] and \( R \approx 6.4 \times 10^6 \units{m} \) is the radius of the earth. Thus, we find \[ a_c \approx 0.034 \unitsf{m}{s^2} \] which is extremely small -- compare \( g \approx 9.8 \units{m/s} \). Thus, reference frames on earth are practically inertial.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Experiment demonstrating Newton's second law.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: \( m_1 a_1 = m_2 a_2 \) means that the same force on an object with 10 times the mass will produce 1/10th the acceleration.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Newton's second law: \[ \mathbf F = m \mathbf a \] a net force on an object produces an acceleration in the direction of that force, proportional to the mass of the object.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Force has units \[ \units{\left[ mass \right] \cdot \left[ acceleration \right]} \rightarrow \unitsf{kg\ m}{s^2} \] This is called a "Newton".

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Newton's second law also only holds in inertial reference frames.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Because the acceleration due to earth's gravity (near the surface) is a constant \( g = 9.8 \units{m/s^2} \), we can write a *force* due to gravity as \[ F_g = m g \] This force is always directed down towards the earth's center.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: A ball of mass \( m \) resting on a table will experience a gravitational force \( F_g = m g \). Because it is not accelerating, we know there must be no net force on the ball. The table must exert a "normal force" \( F_N = - mg \)  to balance the gravitational force. Thus, \( F_g + F_N = 0 \), and the ball is not accelerating.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: The "normal force" is generated when two objects are in contact with each other. It is always directed perpendicular to the surface of contact (*normal* is a synonym for *perpendicular*).

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: Newton's second law implies that if we know the mass of an object and the forces acting on it, the acceleration is uniquely determined. We do *not* need to know anything about its speed! Thus, Newton's 2nd law holds equally well for a stationary object as for one in constant motion. Disclaimer: when velocities near the speed of light, Newtonian mechanics no longer hold and we must use relativity.

name: Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws
note_content: End of MIT Lecture on Newton's 1st and 2nd Laws

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Newton's Third Law: If one object exerts a force on another, the other exerts the same force, in the opposite direction, on the one.

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Students can often repeat Newton's third law, but don't really understand when it comes time to do a problem. *Any* time two bodies exert a force on each other, the forces are always equal and opposite!

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: "Action" = - "Reaction"

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Newton's Third law *always* holds, whether objects are accelerating or not!

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Example of Newton's 2nd law; Force on two blocks, find acceleration of whole system

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Example of Newton's 2nd law, to find the force \( F_{12} \)

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Example of Newton's 2nd law, to find the force \( F_{21} \)

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: These forces are consistent with Newton's 3rd law!

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: End of MIT Lecture on Newton's 3rd Law.

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Beginning of misconceptions video about Newton's 3rd Law.

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: The force attracting the moon to the earth is exactly the same size as the force attracting the earth to the moon. This is a consequence of Newton's third law!

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: The earth doesn't move very much because it is much more massive. By Newton's 2nd law, the same force will produce a greater acceleration for the moon (which has a much smaller mass) than for the earth (which has a much larger mass).

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: You've got to internalize Newton's third law so it comes naturally when solving problems! Whenever two bodies are interacting via some force, that force is *the same size* -- the force exerted on body 1 by body 2 is equal and opposite to the force exerted on body 2 by body 1!

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: Intuitive explanation of Newton's third law.

name: Newton's 3rd Law
note_content: End of misconceptions video about Newton's 3rd Law

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: Involved example with Newton's laws.

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: A mass \( m \) hangs from two strings attached to the ceiling, one at \( 60^\circ \) and one at \( 45^\circ \). Find the tensional force in each string.

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
question: What is the \( \uvec y \)-component of the gravitational force on the mass?
explanation: The \( \uvec y \)-component of the gravitational force is \( -mg \). Because we drew the y-axis to point upwards, the gravitational force (which points downwards) shows up as a negative -- that is, it is in the opposite direction as the positive y-axis. There is no \( \uvec x \)-component, because the gravitational force always points straight down.

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: We know from Newton's 2nd law that \[ \mathbf F = m \mathbf a = 0 \] since the mass is not moving.

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: We can decompose the vector \( \mathbf F \) into \( \hat x \) and \( \hat y \) components.

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: \[ \sum F_x = 0, \sum F_y = 0 \]

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
question: What is the component of \( T_1 \) in the \( \uvec x \) direction?
explanation: We want to take the component of \( \mathbf T_1 \) in the x-direction. From the problem, we know that \( T_1 \) makes an angle of \( 60^\circ \) with the x-axis, and so by drawing in the appropriate right triangle we see that the leg along the x-axis has a magnitude of \( T_1 \cos 60^\circ \).

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: \[ \sum F_x = T_1 \cos 60^\circ - T_2 \cos 45^\circ = 0 \] \[ \sum F_x = \frac{1}{2} T_1 - \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} T_2 = 0 \]

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: \[ \sum F_y = T_1 \sin 60^\circ + T_2 \sin 45^\circ - mg = 0 \] \[ \sum F_y = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} T_1 + \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} T_2 - mg= 0 \]

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: Solving for \( T_1 \) by adding the two equations, we see that \[ \frac{1}{2} T_1 + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} T_1 = mg \] and so \[ T_1 = \frac{2 m g}{1+ \sqrt{3}} \]

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content:
These types of problems are known as "static equilibrium" problems, and can always be solved by 
\begin{align} &\text{1). Drawing the free body diagram, } \\ 
&\text{2). Writing down the sum of the forces in the \( \uvec x \) and \( \uvec y \) directions (which are equal to zero, because the mass is not accelerating), and} \\ 
&\text{3). Solving for the desired quantities.} \end{align}

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: Plugging back in and solving for \( T_2 \), we see \[ \frac{1}{2} T_1 = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2} T_2 \rightarrow \] \[ T_2 = \frac{T_1}{\sqrt{2}} \]

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: Same problem, but using a clever vector addition trick! We know from Newton's 2nd law that \[ \mathbf T_1 + \mathbf T_2 + m \mathbf g = 0 \] If we flip the vector \( m \mathbf g \) over, we get a figure which allows us to easily calculate \( T_1 \) and \( T_2 \) by taking the projection of \( m \mathbf g \) onto each of these rays.

name: Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass
Video Description: MIT - Example of Newton's Laws with Hanging Mass (Lecture 6)
note_content: End of example.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: MIT: Weight and Weightlessness

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: If you stand on a bathroom scale, you exert a force \( \mathbf F = m \mathbf g \) on the scale (measured in Newtons, \(  \units{N} \) ). Weight is defined as the force that the scale exerts on you, \( \mathbf F_s \), in accordance with Newton's 3rd law.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: You are in an elevator rising with an acceleration of \(\mathbf a\). Gravity exerts a downward force \( \mathbf F_g = mg \) on you, and the scale exerts an upward force \( \mathbf F_s \) on you.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content:
Acceleration due to gravity: \[ g = + 9.8 \unitsf{m}{s^2} \]
Conventionally, the gravitational acceleration constant \( g \) is always positive, but make sure you keep track of direction when you solve problems! The gravitational force always points straight down.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
question: Which of the following is true? \begin{align} &\text{1). } F_s < mg \\ &\text{2). } F_s = mg \\ &\text{3). } F_s > mg \end{align} (enter number only)
explanation: We use Newton's second law to write a force-balance equation: \[ F_s - mg = m a \] Because the elevator has a positive upward acceleration, \( F_s - mg > 0 \) and so \( F_s > mg \).

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: Use Newton's second law: \[ \mathbf{F_s} - m\mathbf{g} = m\mathbf{a}\]

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: Rising in an elevator (where upwards \(\mathbf a\) is positive): \[ \mathbf{F_s} = m(\mathbf a +\mathbf g)\]

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: Your *apparent weight* is \( \mathbf F_s \). This is the normal force exerted by the scale! Thus, in an accelerating elevator, you gain weight (even though your mass stays the same).

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: Falling in an elevator (where downwards \(\mathbf a\) is positive): \begin{align*} m\mathbf{g} - \mathbf{F_s}  &= m\mathbf{a}  \\ \mathbf{F_s} &= m(\mathbf g - \mathbf a) \end{align*}

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: In free fall, where \(\mathbf a = \mathbf g\), you will be weightless.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: Defintion of free fall: When the forces acting on a body are exclusively gravitational.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: We can equivalently measure weight by a tensional force required to support our body -- it makes no difference whether the weight force ( \( \mathbf F_w \) ) is supplied by the normal force from a scale, or by a tensional force in a rope.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: Imagine that you are hanging onto a string attached to a tension scale on the ceiling of an elevator. The tension in the string is \( T \), and the acceleration upwards is \( a \): \begin{align*} \mathbf T - m\mathbf g = m\mathbf a \\ T = m(\mathbf a + \mathbf g) \end{align*}. This is the same equation that we got with the bathroom scale. Tension is an indicator of weight.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
question: What is the definition of weight?
answer: Weight of an object is defined as the force due to gravity. Thus, \( \text{Weight} = mg \). This is contrasted with *apparent weight*, which is what Prof. Lewin discusses in this video.
explanation: Traditionally, *weight* is a synonym for the force of gravity -- \( \text{Weight} = F_g = mg \). The *apparent weight* of an object is the force one would read on a scale. It will change, depending on whether the object is accelerating, and is equal to the force required to cause that acceleration (and must be supplied by a normal force from the ground/scale, or a tension in a rope, for example). Be careful with these!

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
question: What is the definition of free-fall?
answer: Free-fall occurs when your apparent weight goes to zero.
explanation: This happens when you accelerate at the rate of gravity, \( g \), because then (by Newton's second law) there are no other forces on you other than the force of gravity. Thus, there will be no normal force (eg, from a scale) or tension (eg, from a hanging rope) to supply a force giving you non-zero apparent weight.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
question: What are the units of weight?
explanation: Weight, remember, is a force! It should not be confused with mass, even though the two are often used interchangeably in common speech.

name: Introduction to Weight
Video Description: MIT - Introduction to Weight and Weightlessness (Lecture 7)
note_content: End of introduction to weight

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Begin example of ice sliding down an incline

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Problem setup: A block of ice with mass \( m = 10 \units{kg} \) is sitting on a wedge (also made of ice) with an angle of \( \theta = 30^\circ \) to the ground. We want to calculate the motion of the block.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Force of gravity \( F_g = m g \) points downward, and acts at the center of mass of the block.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Because motion will be along the surface of the block, we decompose the force of gravity into components that are perpendicular and parallel to the surface of the block.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Using some trig, we find that the component of \( F_g \) that is perpendicular to the surface is \[ F_{g,\perp} = F_g \cos \theta = m g \cos \theta \]

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Similarly, the parallel component is \[ F_{g,\parallel} = F_g \sin \theta = m g \sin \theta \]

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: A good mnemonic for this is "Sine Slides" -- you use "Sine" to get the component that would cause the block to "Slide" along the wedge.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Another good way to figure out which trig function to use is by limiting cases. As \( \theta \rightarrow 0 \), there should be no component parallel to the surface, because the block would be sitting on flat ground. Since \( \sin 0 = 0 \) while \( \cos 0 = 1 \), we want to use sine for the parallel component.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: If the component of the gravitational force \( F_{g,\perp} \) were the only force acting perpendicular to the plane of the wedge, then by Newton's 2nd law the block would accelerate downward into the wedge. Because this does not happen, there must be another force opposing it. This is the *Normal Force*.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content:
The normal force \( F_N \) is always normal (perpendicular) to the surface, and here we reasoned it must oppose the perpendicular component of \( F_g \). Thus, 
\[ F_N = - F_{g,\perp} = m g \cos \theta \text{ outward } \]

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: There is no frictional force opposing \( F_{g,\parallel} \), and so the block will experience an acceleration by Newton's 2nd law.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content:
\[ \mathbf F = m \mathbf a \rightarrow F_{g, \parallel} = m a \]
\[ m g \sin \theta = m a \rightarrow \]
\[ a = g \sin \theta \]

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: Notice that the acceleration is independent of the mass of the block! This is because the force due to gravity is proportional to the mass while the acceleration is inversely proportional to the mass, and so the mass of the block drops out of our equation entirely.

name: Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
Video Description: Khan - Example - Block sliding down frictionless plane
note_content: End of example

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: Kinematics motion in 3-D space

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: In general, the "position" of an object is designated by a vector (in three dimensions), and is given the variable \( \mathbf r \).

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: \[ mathbf r_t = x_t \uvec x + y_t \uvec y + z_t \uvec z \]

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: \[ \mathbf v_t = \frac{dr_t}{dt} = \dot x_t \uvec x + \dot y_t \uvec y + \dot z_t \uvec z \]

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: \[ \mathbf a_t = \frac{dv_t}{dt} = \ddot x_t \uvec x + \ddot y_t \uvec y + ddot z_t \uvec z \]

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: By writing the 3-D motion in terms of vector components, we have broken a complex problem into three simpler 1-D problems!

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: When solving kinematics problems, you'll almost always want to break things up into components -- separate equations for each direction. First though, it is *very* important to define your coordinate system! This way, both you and your professor/grader know which direction is \( + \uvec x \), say, and which direction is \( - \uvec x \).

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: Overview of kinematics

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: For complex 3-D motion, decompose the motion (always described by the position vector, \( \mathbf r(t) \) ) into three independent 1-D problems along the \( \uvec x, \uvec y \) and \( \uvec z \) axes. We can then use the standard kinematics equations to solve!

name: Kinematics motion in 3-D space
note_content: End of 3-D kinematics

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
note_content: Example - Projectile motion in a plane

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
note_content:
1D motion, constant acceleration equations: 
\begin{align} x(t) &= x_0 + v_{0,x} t + frac{1}{2}a_{x} t^2 \\ 
v_{x}(t) &= v_{0,x} + a_x t \\ 
a_{x}(t) &= a_x \end{align}

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
note_content: It can be useful to analyze the motion of objects with regard to only one axis at a time. This is one reason why it is important to choose your coordinate system well at the start of the problem

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
question: Why isn't the velocity \( v_x \) in the \( \uvec x \) direction going to change?
answer: Because there are no forces in the \( \uvec x \) direction.
explanation: Because there are no forces in the \( \uvec x \) direction, there will be no acceleration in the \( \uvec x \) direction (by Newton's 2nd law) and hence the velocity will not change.

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
question: What is the acceleration in the \( \uvec y \) direction at time \( t = 0.5 \) seconds? (numbers only, no units)
explanation: The acceleration in the \( \uvec y \)-direction is *always* \( -9.8 \units{m/s^2} \), because the only *force* acting in the \( \uvec y \)-direction is the force due to gravity. By Newton's 2nd law, we get \[ F_g = - m g = m a \rightarrow \] \[ a = -g \]

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
note_content: Acceleration due to gravity only affects velocity in the y direction

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
note_content: Demonstration of independence of movement in several axes

name: Example - Projectile motion in a plane
Video Description: MIT - Example of projectile motion in a plane
note_content: End of example on projectile motion.

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: A young monkey is in a tree, searching for tasty bananas. On the ground, a monkey hunter aims a golf ball gun straight at the monkey. The golf ball leaves the the gun at a velocity \( v_0 \), and lands at point P. When the monkey sees the flash of the gun, it lets go of the branch it is hanging from and begins to fall. Is the monkey safe, or is it the last day for the monkey?

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: The ball's horizontal position at time \( t \) is not affected by the existence of gravity. The position \( x(t_1) \) of the ball at time \( t_1 \) is the same for the hunter's assumed trajectory, which ignores gravity, and its actual trajectory, which is affected by gravity.

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: The \( y \)-position of the ball can cleverly found by finding the difference in \( y \)-value between the assumed trajectory (no gravity) and the actual trajectory (with gravity).

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content:
With gravity, the y-position is:
\[ y(t) = \left[ v_0\sin(\alpha) \right] t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \]

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content:
Without gravity, we no longer have a force in the \( \uvec y \)-direction and hence no acceleration in the \( \uvec y \)-direction. Thus, \( g \rightarrow 0 \) and
\[ y(t) = \left[ v_0\sin(\alpha) \right] t \]

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
question: In terms of the given variables, how much further below the monkey's original position will the ball hit the tree?

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: The ball will land \( \frac{1}{2}g{t_2}^2\)  below the monkey's original position. That is exactly the same distance that the monkey will fall if it lets go at exactly \(t_0\)! If it lets go, the monkey will be killed :-(

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: This result is independent of the initial velocity of the gun!

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: Consider the same situation, except that both the monkey and the hunter are in an elevator undergoing free-fall motion, and so also accelerating at \( 9.8 \units{m/s^2} \). In this case, the bullet will come straight at the monkey since the force of gravity is acting on all of them, not just the bullet, and so they are all accelerating at the same rate.

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: If the horizontal distance between the hunter and the monkey is \( D \) and the height of the tree is \( h \), the length of the trajectory in the monkey-hunter frame is \( \sqrt{D^2 + h^2} \).

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
question: What is \(t_{\text{kill}}\), the amount of time that the monkey has left to live from the moment the bullet is fired?
explanation: The amount of time it takes the bullet to reach the monkey is just the distance divided by the velocity. In the monkey-hunter frame, the velocity of the bullet is \( v_0 \), and travels the hypotenuse distance of the triangle shown. Thus,

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: In the inertial frame of the classroom (outside the elevator), we see a different picture! We see the bullet traveling with a horizontal velocity \( v_x = v_0 \cos \alpha \), over a distance \( D \). Thus, we calculate \[ t_{\text{kill}} = \frac{D}{v_0 \cos \alpha} \]

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: Using \( \cos \alpha = \frac{D}{sqrt{D^2 + h^2}} \) from the geometry of the image, we can see that both values for \(t_{\text{kill}}\) turn out identical!

name: Example - Monkey hunting and projectile motion
Video Description: MIT - Example of a monkey and a hunter
note_content: \(t_{kill}\) should be the same regardless of the chosen reference frame.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: Uniform circular motion - An object goes around in a circle at some radius \( r \) with some angular frequency \( \omega \).

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: The velocity is always tangential to the circle. As the object moves around in a circle, the velocity is changing (because it is a vector quantity, and its direction is changing) but the speed remains constant for *uniform* circular motion.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: Period - The time it takes for one complete revolution. Written \( T \), and measured in seconds.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content:
Frequency - The number of rotations per second. Written \( f \) or \( \nu \), and measured in \( \units{s^{-1}} \equiv \units{Hertz} \). 
\[ f = \frac{1}{T} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: Angular Velocity - The number of radians per second (analogous to velocity, with "distance" being measured in "radians"). Written \( \omega \), and measured in \( \units{s^{-1}} \), or Herts. \[ \omega = 2 \pi f  = \frac{2 \pi}{T} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: \[ v = \omega r \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: The speed of the rotating object is not changing, but the velocity is! Therefore, there *must* be an acceleration, this is "non-negotiable."

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: The acceleration is always directed to the center.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content:
The acceleration is called "centripital acceleration", \( a_c \), and one can show that 
\[ \mathbf a_c = \frac{v^2}{r} \text{ towards the center } \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content:
\[ \begin{align} a_c &= \frac{v^2}{r} \\
v &= \omega r \rightarrow \\
a_c = \frac{(\omega r)^2}{r} = \omega^2 r 
\end{align} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: "Centripetal acceleration" is the name of *any* acceleration towards the center of the circle. Later we'll discuss "centripetal force", which is just the *name* of *whatever force(s)* point towards the center! Thus, it is best to think of "centripetal" as a direction. Just like "normal" refers to the perpendicular direction, "centripetal" refers to the direction towards the center of the circle.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
question: A vacuum rotor has radius \( r = 10 \units{cm} \) and rotates at \( 600 \units{rpm} \). What is its frequency of rotation in Hertz? (number only)
explanation: \( 600 \units{rpm} \) is 600 revolutions per minute, meaning it undergoes \[ 600 \unitsf{rev}{minute} \cdot \unitsf{1 min}{60 sec} = 10 \unitsf{1}{sec} \rightarrow 10 \units{Hz} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: \( 600 \units{rpm} \) translates into \[ 600 \unitsf{rotations}{minute} \cdot \unitsf{1 minute}{60 seconds} \rightarrow 10 \units{Hz} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: The period is \[ T = \frac{1}{f} = \frac{1}{10} \units{sec} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: The angular velocity is \[ \omega = \frac{2\pi}{T} = 2 \pi f \approx 63 \unitsf{rad}{sec} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: The speed, \( v \), is just \[ v = \omega r \approx 6.3 \units{m}{s} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
question: What is the definition of centripetal acceleration?
answer: \[ a_c = \omega^2 r \] or equivalently (for uniform circular motion) \[ a_c = \frac{v^2}{r} \]

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content:
The centripetal acceleration is \( a_c = \omega^2 r = \frac{v^2}{r} \) and so
\[ a_c = \omega^2 r \approx 400 \unitsf{m}{s^2} \] This is enormous!

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: Be careful! The centripetal acceleration is *linear* in the radius \( r \) -- \( a_c = \omega^2 r \). It is *not* inversely proportional to \( r \), as you might guess from the relation \( a_c = \frac{v^2}{r} \). This is because the velocity is proportional to \( r \) -- If you are sitting at the center of a rotating disk, you would have zero velocity.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: END of introduction to centripetal acceleration

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: Begin introduction to centripetal force

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: Imagine you are sitting on a turntable rotating at angular velocity \( \omega \) at a distance \( r \) from the center.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: You must experience a centripetal acceleration \( a_c = \omega^2 r \), this is non-negotiable because your velocity is changing!

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
question: What force is producing the centripetal acceleration required to keep you moving in a uniform circle?
answer: The centripetal acceleration is caused by some contact force between you and the chair, which is bolted to the turn table.
explanation: This centripetal acceleration must come from somewhere -- By Newton's 2nd law, accelerations must be caused by a force! Your chair is bolted to the turntable, so that force is supplied by some contact force between you and the chair/turntable.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: This centripetal acceleration must come from somewhere -- By Newton's 2nd law, accelerations must be caused by a force! Your chair is bolted to the turntable, so that force is supplied by some contact force between you and the chair/turntable.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: The force that causes your circular motion is called the "centripetal force." *Centripetal* means "towards the center," that is, it is the force directed towards the center causing your circular acceleration.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: If the centripetal force disappears, you will fly off in whatever direction your velocity vector is pointing. That is, you will fly off in a straight line tangent to the circle!

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: Demonstration of circular motion.

name: Centripetal forces and accelerations
note_content: END of introduction to centripetal force
